title: Electricity: I spend N40,000 monthly on petrol, N6,000 on prepaid meter
text:
Home » News » Electricity: I spend N40,000 monthly on petrol, N6,000 on prepaid meter Electricity: I spend N40,000 monthly on petrol, N6,000 on prepaid meter On 10:20 pm In News by Tony Comments 
Some electricity consumers in Aguda area of Surulere, Lagos, on Tuesday complained about the epileptic power supply and outrageous billing by Eko Electricity Distribution Company (EKEDC). 
In separate interviews with newsmen in Lagos they complained that incessant power outage had crippled economic activities in the area thereby made life unbearable. 
In his comments, Mr Tunde Akinfenwa, a resident, told pressmen that the epileptic power supply made life difficult for the residents, especially with the prevailing hot weather. 
Akinfenwa said that he spent about N10, 000 weekly to buy petrol and engine oil to fuel his generating set. 
“The weather is hot, especially in the night, and if I can manage to sleep, my two boys cannot sleep well without electricity because of the heat. 
“I am spending close to N40,000 monthly on petrol, while I recharge N6,000 on my prepaid meter. 
“I don’t mind spending the whole amount on billing, if power supply could be regular,’’ he said. 
Akinfenwa appealed to EKEDC to improve on the electricity supply to the area to encourage consumers to pay their monthly bills. 
Another resident, Mrs Josephine Okoro, said that she always received N10, 000 on estimated billing monthly from the company in spite of the erratic power supply. 
Okoro said she had requested for prepaid meter, but EKEDC kept bringing outrageous bills instead of installing the building with functional prepaid meter. 
“Few of us with analogue meters have vowed not to pay the monthly bills unless our buildings are installed with prepaid meters. 
“How can I get a bill of N10, 000 with just few days of power supply in a month; this is unfair to those of us with analogue meters. 
“EKEDC should do something about our meters because the estimated billing is unbearable,’’ she said. 
Also, Alhaji Folorunso Ishola, a resident, said it was disheartened to see neighbouring community enjoying regular power supply, while Aguda Community remained in perpetual darkness. 
Ishola appealed to EKEDC to improve electricity supply to the area. 
Responding, Mr Godwin Idemudia, the General Manager, Corporate Communications Unit of EKEDC, pleaded with the consumers of the affected areas to show understanding. 
Idemudia said that the drop in power allocation from the national grid was responsible for the epileptic power supply being experienced in the area. 
He assured the consumers that the company would do its best to ensure improved power supply was restored to the area. 
Idemudia urged them not to resort to vandalism of the company equipment as a result of the epileptic supply.
